abstract.p: This article presents active control laws for sound transmission through a stiffened panel in the low-frequency range. A stiffened panel mounted on a metallic box is used to simulate aircraft fuselage and cabin system. A loudspeaker located outside the box is driven by band-limited white noise to exert acoustic excitation. Dynamic properties of the stiffened panel are characterized through a series of modal testing. Sound isolation performance is evaluated both analytically and experimentally for further efficient control algorithms design. Based on the analysis of these results, a hybrid control strategy combining both feedback and feedforward control is proposed, which utilizes a high-authority/low-authority control architecture. The low-authority control loop is positive position feedback control and high-authority control loop is filtered-X control. When positive position feedback is implemented, active damping is added on the secondary path, which makes filtered-X least mean square more robust, accelerates convergence rates, and reduces residue errors. In the end, the effectiveness of the hybrid control is verified through a serious of closed-loop control experiments. These results demonstrate that sound pressure level could be lowered by a maximum of 15.9 dB at the first resonance frequency. In addition, the overall sound reduction in the cabin is more than 7 dB.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Lightweight structures have been extensively applied in airplanes, which raises the issue of noise transmission into aircraft cabin, especially at low frequencies (Nelson and Elliott, 1992). The main cabin noise is generated by aircraft engines and turbulent boundary noise (Wilby, 1996). When an aircraft flies, these two types of noise will impinge on the fuselage persistently. This gives rise to large decibels of both airborne and structure-borne noise, which leads to potential hearing loss to passengers and crew members and makes the flight less comfortable. Thus, the reduction of cabin noise is an increasingly major concern in commercial civil aviation.

Many passive control methods have been developed to suppress low-frequency noise, which requires bulk and heavy materials. However, these methods are impractical for commercial aircraft since large mass and volume are required. Active controls are therefore proposed as practical alternatives to effectively attenuate sound level of the cabin in low-frequency band, which can be mounted on the fuselage or airframe structures.

Many efforts have been taken to develop active control techniques, which can generally be classified into two categories. The first one is active noise control (ANC) (Kuo and Morgan, 1999; Nelson and Elliott, 1992; Qiu and Ji, 2010). The basic idea that was first proposed by Leug has been known for nearly 80 years. Following this approach, loudspeakers are used as secondary sources, and antiphase signal of unwanted noise is generated to interference with the primary sound field. The secondary one is active structural acoustic control (ASAC), which usually employs secondary force actuators to reduce noise transmission and radiation of vibrating structures (Clark and Fuller, 1991; Fuller et al., 1997).

With respect to globe control, the number of secondary loudspeakers rises in proportion to the cube of the excitation frequency in a three-dimensional enclosure (Elliott, 1994). Thus, it is almost impossible to realize global broadband sound control within a reasonable number of secondary loudspeakers in a complex enclosure, whereas ASAC approach usually employ only a few actuators and produce global far-field attenuation. Therefore, ASAC is a more promising solution for cabin noise control. For instance, Pinte et al. (2009) proposed iterative learning control for active control repetitive impact noise. Gardonio et al. (2004a, 2004b, 2004c) developed collocated direct velocity feedback (DVF) control with 16 accelerometers and 16 piezoelectric patches for sound radiation control, which obtains 8–13 dB sound reduction at the first three resonance frequencies. Radiation modes and radiation modal expansion are investigated to decouple sound radiation from structural vibration modes and are applied to practical real-time control (Gibbs et al., 2000; Noelle and Cunefare, 1995). Since the first radiation mode accounts the most sound radiation energy in low frequencies, which has a close relationship to its net volume velocity, thus volume velocity control has proven to be an effective strategy to reduce overall sound radiation, which is discussed by Johnson and Elliott (1995) and Sors and Elliott (2002). With the identified model, control system is designed according to H∞ specification to suppress noise radiated from a vibrating structure (Choi, 2006; Miyashita et al., 2005). The concept of vibroacoustic modes has also been proposed, and control object is to control both sound and vibration simultaneously (Kaizuka and Tanaka, 2008). Besides, some active control projects concerning helicopter and propeller aircraft have been carried out to make the whole system more practical (Belanger et al., 2008; Chen et al., 2004; Grewal et al., 2001; Palumbo et al., 2001).

Although much work has been done in this area, there still exist some gaps to fill. For instance, filtered-X least mean square (FXLMS) control has been proven to be a successful strategy for active control; however, its robustness and convergence rate still need to be improved. Various hybrid control methods are also needed to be fully investigated since a proper hybrid control strategy could improve one or more features than using one control algorithm alone. In this article, a hybrid control using positive position feedback (PPF) and FXLMS control is proposed. The damping effect on the secondary path that has a positive influence on FXLMS is also investigated, which has not been paid enough attention.

In section “Dynamic properties of the stiffened panel,” a stiffened panel is presented to mimic real aircraft fuselage, which is usually combined with stiffeners and bays; this also means the control object is quite realistic and complex. In section “Experimental system setup,” basic parameters of the panel are given first, and a modal test is taken to investigate its dynamic properties. Radiation characteristics of the panel at the first resonance frequency are explored analytically and experimentally in section “Sound transmission analysis focusing on the first vibration mode.” Control algorithms are developed in section “Control architecture and algorithms” on the basis of above research. A hybrid control strategy is proposed, which utilizes a high-authority control (HAC)/low-authority control (LAC) architecture. The HAC strategy is a feedforward FXLMS control, and LAC utilizes PPF control. The benefits of this hybrid control are discussed in section “Analysis of the benefits of PPF/FXLMS hybrid control.” In the ‘Experimental results’ section, control algorithms proposed above are implemented for active control and control results are compared, which verify the effectiveness of this hybrid control strategy.

sec.title: Dynamic properties of the stiffened panel
sec.p: The stiffened panel built for this study is an aluminum panel of thickness 1 mm, representative of real aircraft skin. Four stiffeners divide this panel into nine rectangular bays. As shown in Figure 1, the dimension is length × width = 820 mm × 516 mm, and bays are not evenly divided by these stiffeners.

However, “experimental study of structure dynamics has always provided a major contribution to our efforts to understand and control the many vibration phenomena encountered in practice” (Ewins, 2001). Therefore, an experimental modal analysis is conducted using a Laser Scanning Vibrometer PSV-300 from Polytec Inc. to identify vibration modes of the stiffened panel.

In modal testing, the stiffened panel is clamped to a rigid framework, which was hanged vertically by rubber ropes. This arrangement is shown in Figure 2(a). Then a shaker driven by a power amplifier is used to exert point force excitation through a rod, which is vertical to the panel and has the characteristic of being stiff only in this direction. One hundred twenty-six points evenly distributed on the panel surface are selected for measurement, where the horizontal number is 9 and vertical number is 14. These discrete points are scanned one by one automatically by the scanning control system, and their surface transverse vibration velocities are measured. Random signals are selected to excite the test structure, and frequency response function (FRF) estimations are computed to derive the panel’s mode shapes. The arrangement of modal test experiment is shown in Figure 2.

The averaged spectrum of vibration velocity is shown in Figure 3, and the first 10 mode shapes and natural frequencies of the stiffened panel are shown in Figure 4. From Figure 4, it can be seen that the first vibration mode behaves like a monopole radiator, while local mode is notable at high frequencies. Besides, these mode shapes also indicate that central part of the stiffened panel is relatively easier to be excited than other parts; thus, it becomes the main radiation area where active control is needed.

Figure 5 shows a schematic diagram of the experimental system setup for active sound transmission control with acoustic excitation. Parts of the inner surfaces of the cavity are covered with sound-absorbing materials called “bass trap.” These materials are suitable for low-frequency sound absorption and cost relatively less than ordinary acoustic wedge absorbers. Acoustic wools are also adhered to other regions of the cavity. From these above arrangements, the cavity can be regarded as a simply equipped anechoic chamber.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of the active cabin noise control platform.

sec.p: A 1/4-inch microphone sensor is located inside the cavity and installed on a tripod. The distance is 50 cm away from central part of the panel to satisfy far-field requirement (Bies and Hansen, 2009). The microphone has two functions: one is used for adaptive control; the other is used for measurement and control performance evaluation. The sensitivity of the microphone is 50 mV/Pa and is made by G.A.R.S. Sound & Vibration (G.R.A.S).

A 6.5-inch loudspeaker outside the cavity is used as the acoustic excitation source to generate low-frequency noise disturbance. The loudspeaker is placed about 20 cm away, and the cone of loudspeaker is placed parallel to the central bay of the stiffened panel.

The loudspeaker is used to generate enough diffuse acoustic excitation on the central bay, where active control needs to be implemented. Sound pressure level (SPL) before and after control can be obtained to verify control effects.

sec.title: Control architecture and algorithms
sec.p: Active control is actually a disturbance rejection problem in control engineering, and it is very important to select an appropriate control strategy. For complex structures, HAC/LAC architecture has been chosen to act as an effective control strategy to suppress vibration (Aubrun, 1984). In this study, we select this control architecture and utilize combined feedback with feedforward control to active control sound transmission of the panel.

In the LAC loop, usually simple but robust algorithms are implemented to generate damping to the structure and make it less sensitive to disturbance; however, controller robustness is at the cost of control performance. In the HAC loop, complex control algorithms are implemented targeting some specific control objectives. For instance, we can use FXLMS control algorithm or other control methods to minimize the mean square error signal of the microphone sensor. These two control loops usually behave independently, but their control effects are complementary, which will make the whole system more robust and efficient than using only one control method alone.

From the analysis and experimental results in section “Sound transmission analysis focusing on the first vibration mode,” the first vibration mode radiates more efficiently than other modes, and radiation is dominated by structure damping coefficient; thus more control authority should be focused on this mode. PPF controller is chosen to serve as a robust active damping unit to damp the first vibration mode, which makes up LAC loop. There also exists another famous LAC law called collocated DVF control. However, the reason we do not use it is that this controller exert its control effort on all frequencies, including both resonance frequencies and nonresonance frequencies, whereas PPF only focuses its control authority on targeting one frequency nearby. FXLMS feedforward adaptive control is implemented for broadband control in the HAC loop to minimize sound pressure at the error microphone sensor.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: Since piezoelectric materials can be used both as sensors and actuators (Tani et al., 1998), they have been used widely in active control of sound radiation. In this control experiment, three lead zirconate titanate (PZT) patches (No. 1–No. 3) are used as actuators, and one patch is used as a sensor, which is collocated with No. 2 patch. Sensor and actuator locations are presented in Figure 15, and physical parameters and dimensions of PZT patch are shown in Table 1.

Control algorithms are implemented on a Compact Reconfigurable IO (compact RIO) real-time control target, which is a rugged reconfigurable embedded controller and acquisition system from National Instruments (NI). The controller type is 9024, analog input module is 9215, and analog output module is 9263; control algorithms are written in LabVIEW. A signal conditioner 2693-OS-4 from B&K is used to provide necessary Integrated Circuits Piezoelectric (ICP) current supply to a microphone sensor. The overall test rig and experimental facilities are shown in Figure 16.

sec.title: FXLMS control results
sec.p: The FXLMS algorithm is implemented in this subsection. The actuator patches are No. 1 and No. 3, and the microphone sensor inside the cavity is used as an error sensor. The secondary path from the piezoelectric patches excited by band-limited white noise to the microphone sensor is first identified off-line using a traditional LMS algorithm and then filter coefficients of the identified secondary path transfer function are copied into FXLMS algorithm. The controller structure is a FIR filter, with the filter length of 128, convergence coefficient of 0.0005, and the sampling frequency of 2 kHz.

Broadband control results are shown in Figure 18. From Figure 18, we can see that after the adaptive control algorithm has converged, the SPL reduction is 8.26 dB at the first natural frequency, and the overall SPL attenuation in the frequency range of 0–1 kHz is 4.8 dB.

sec.title: Hybrid control results
sec.p: In the end, proposed hybrid control law is implemented, which simultaneously combines a FXLMS and PPF control. Both sensor and actuator configurations are the same as stated in sections “PPF control results” and “FXLMS control results.”

Open-loop and closed-loop SPL averaged responses are compared in Figure 19. From Figure 19, a maximum of 15.59-dB reduction at the frequency of the first resonance mode is obtained when using proposed hybrid control strategy. An overall SPL attenuation in the frequency band of 0–1 kHz is 7.01 dB, which are 2.21 dB and 4.99 dB larger than FXLMS and PPF control, respectively. These control results demonstrate that the proposed hybrid control is an effective solution for sound radiation control, which enjoys the merits of LAC/HAC architecture illustrated in the previous section.

As discussed in the former section, the PPF in the hybrid control can accelerate the convergence as well as reduce the residual error of the FXLMS. Hence, the noise attenuation of the hybrid control is larger than the sum of the attenuations of the two control methods when they are executed separately due to their coupling effect.
The final results of SPL reduction at the first natural frequency and the overall SPL reduction results are summarized in Figures 20 and 21 at the end of this section.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Comprehensive works concerning active control laws of sound transmission through a stiffened panel are investigated. Dynamic properties of the panel and sound transmission characteristics are analyzed for controller design. Damping effects to FXLMS are analyzed, and a hybrid control strategy combining feedforward adaptive FXLMS control with PPF control is proposed. Control laws are implemented to control sound transmission through a stiffened panel. Each control method does not require much structure modeling information and can be compatible with each another. Moreover, the hybrid controller becomes more robust and exhibits higher performance.
